intro: Alnus ferruginea var. aliso, commonly known as the Aliso Creek alder, is a deciduous shrub or small tree native to California. It is characterized by its compound leaves, which are alternate and consist of 7–15 pairs of oval, serrated leaflets. The plant produces small, yellowish-green catkins that are typically male, while female flowers are found on the same plant. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in riparian zones and along stream banks. This species is valued for its ecological role in stabilizing soils and providing habitat for wildlife.
